items.label: rem-qsd-vs-true-stationarity
items.title: QSD Stationarity vs. True Stationarity
items.content:
530: :label: rem-qsd-vs-true-stationarity
531: 
532: For a finite N-particle system, the Quasi-Stationary Distribution $\nu_N^{QSD}$ satisfies a **modified stationarity condition** that accounts for the non-zero probability of eventual extinction. For any test function $\Phi: \Sigma_N \to \mathbb{R}$:
533: 
534: $$
535: \mathbb{E}_{\nu_N^{QSD}}[\mathcal{L}_N \Phi] = -\lambda_N \mathbb{E}_{\nu_N^{QSD}}[\Phi]
536: 
537: $$
538: 
539: where $\lambda_N > 0$ is the **extinction rate** (also called the survival rate or quasi-stationary eigenvalue). This rate characterizes how quickly the conditioned process escapes from the quasi-stationary state toward the absorbing boundary.

items.label: rem-uniqueness-completeness-constraint-set
items.title: Completeness of the Constraint Set $\mathcal{P}$
items.content:
900: :label: rem-uniqueness-completeness-constraint-set
901: 
902: The space $\mathcal{P}$ is a closed subset of the Banach space $H^1_w(\Omega)$, hence complete. This follows from:
903: 
904: 1. **Non-negativity**: The set $\{\rho \in H^1_w : \rho \ge 0 \text{ a.e.}\}$ is closed because if $\rho_n \to \rho$ in $H^1_w$, then $\rho_n \to \rho$ in $L^2_w$, and a subsequence converges almost everywhere. The limit of non-negative functions is non-negative a.e.
905: 
906: 2. **Normalization**: The set $\{\rho \in H^1_w : \int \rho = 1\}$ is closed because the functional $\rho \mapsto \int \rho dz$ is continuous with respect to the $H^1_w$ norm (by Sobolev embedding $H^1_w \hookrightarrow L^1$).
907: 
908: 3. **Intersection of closed sets**: $\mathcal{P}$ is the intersection of these two closed sets, hence closed.

items.label: rem-uniqueness-proof-technique
items.content:
1894: :::{prf:remark}
1895: :label: rem-uniqueness-proof-technique
1896: The proof structure demonstrates a powerful technique in nonlinear analysis: when global Lipschitz continuity fails, we can still prove uniqueness by:
1897: 
1898: 1. **Proving a priori bounds**: Any fixed point must lie in a bounded ball (Lemma [](#lem-uniqueness-fixed-point-boundedness))
1899: 2. **Local contraction**: The operator is a contraction on this bounded ball (Theorem [](#thm-uniqueness-contraction-solution-operator))
1900: 3. **Bootstrapping to global uniqueness**: Since all fixed points lie in the ball, local uniqueness implies global uniqueness
